data.title: Hot Exit does not work on Mac
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.8.1, 1.9.1
- OS Version: OS X EI Capitan

Steps to Reproduce:
VSCode settings:

>   "files.hotExit": "onExit"
"files.autoSave": "off",

1. open a folder
2. create 2 new file, type some words in both files without saving.
3. when closing the instance of the VSCode window, it weirdly asks "Do you want to save the changes you made to the following 2 files", click "Don't Save". Next time, open a new instance of VSCode and open the same folder, the two new files the Untitled-1 and Untitled-2 are opend but both are blank.

another test:
1. open a folder
2. open an existing file
3. make some change to the file without saving.
4. when closing the instance of the VSCode window, it weirdly asks "Do you want to save the changes you made to a.cs", click "Don't Save". Next time, open a new instance of VSCode and open the same folder, but the previously modified file shows nothing changed.

data.title: Test: Command to show which tsconfig/jsconfig project a file belongs to
data.body:
#20356

**OS**
- [x] any @bpasero 
- [x] any @Tyriar 

Complexity 2

1. a new workspace and create a single js file.
2. Open the js file and run the command: `JavaScript: go to project configuration`
3. You should see an alert because no `jsconfig.json` exists.
4. Try creating a jsconfig.json using the alert. This should create an unsaved `jsconfig.json` in the root of your workspace. 
5. Save the empty `jsconfig.json` and try running  `JavaScript: go to project configuration` in the js file again.
6. You should go to the `jsconfig.json` 

Other cases to try out:
*  `TypeScript: go to project configuration` should open/create a `tsconfig.json`
   * If a `jsconfig.json` exists, this will be used as the typescript config instead.
* Try opening javascript files in subdirectories. Currently, the new `tsconfig.json` should always be created in the root.
* Try excluding a file:
  ```json
  {
      "exclude": [
          "myFile.js"
      ]
  }
  ```
  And then running the command in the excluded file. This should show the same alert as when no `jsconfig.json` existed, but the `configure` button should open the existing `jsconfig.json` instead of creating a new one.
* Try creating a project with multiple `jsconfig.json` files in various subdirectories. Make sure we open the right one

data.title: Test: Type Definition Provider

**OS**

Complexity: 1

1. Open the VSCode Codebase and open `extensions/markdown/src/extension.ts`
2. Right click on a variable like `telemetryReporter` in `var telemetryReporter: TelemetryReporter | null;`
3. You should see an option to go to the type definition in the context menu
4. Try going to the definition.
5. This should open `telemetryReporter.d.ts` and go to the `TelemetryReporter`
6. Try using go to type definition in other places in the VSCode codebase and ensure it jumps to the defining type

data.title: Test: JSDoc Auto Complete
data.body:
#20161 #15850

**OS**
- [x] Mac @weinand 
- [x] Windows @mousetraps 
- [x] Linux @Tyriar 

Complexity 2

1. Create a new project with a blank js file.
2. In the js file, trigger suggestions. There should be an entry at the top for JSDoc comments.
3. Try hitting Enter to complete and see that the the comment is inserted.
4. Type out `/**`
5. The suggestion list should show up automatically and the line be read `/**| */`
6. Hit enter to complete the doc
7. create a function like `function add(a, b) { return a + b; }`
8. Try inserting a jsdoc comment before the function. This time, `@param` should be created automatically for `a` and `b`. Both should have `any` type specifiers.
9. Open a ts document and try creating a jsdoc for a function.
10. `@param` should be created but there should be no type specifiers.
11. Try inserting jsdocs in other locations in the file. Only functions currently add any content to the doc.

**Notes**
You should only see a jsdoc suggestion when on blank lines or when starting with a doc comment template. If `|` is the cursor:

```
// These lines all should show the jsdoc completion item when using ctrl+space
|
       |
|xyz
/|
/**|
/**|xyz
ab/**|

// While cases like this should not
ab|
ab.|
```

data.title: Test: Ensure the tsconfig.json validation is exposed
data.body:
#20163

- [x] any @aeschli 

Complexity: 1


Errors should now be shown in invalid jsconfig and tsconfigs. This flow is still pretty buggy and we're tracking a number of fixes/requests on the TS side to support this better. This only tests the basics

1. Create a new project with an empty ts file and an empty `tsconfig.json`
2. Create an invalid option:
  ```json
  {
      "compilerOptions": {
          "notAnOption": true
      }
  }
  ``` 
3. Switch to the ts file. In the errors view you should see:
  ![screen shot 2017-02-21 at 4 26 23 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/23191454/81e428ca-f852-11e6-8cbf-c1738da861c9.png)

4. Change the config to
```json
{
    "files": [
        "notAFile.js"
    ]  
} 
```

5. Switch back to the TS file to see a new error:
  ![screen shot 2017-02-21 at 4 28 55 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/23191504/dc650ac6-f852-11e6-8d2b-f5fbe82ae705.png)

6. Try creating other invalid configs and reloading the project to see them

**Known Issues**
* Errors only show up when working in a js or ts file, not in the `jsconfig` or `tsconfig` itself.
* Config file error are show on the first line at the first character.
* Editing the config file causes the errors to go away

data.title: Test: minimap
data.body:
- [x] any os @chrmarti 
- [x] any os @ramya-rao-a 

Complexity: 2

Please check that:
* you can enable the minimap via `editor.minimap.enabled`
* the minimap always gets the right colors, e.g. when changing themes, when switching a file's language
* on a high dpi display, the minimap uses 4x2 pixels to paint a character, otherwise 2x1 pixels.
* the minimap has its width computed in such a way that it represents the viewport
* the minimap scrolls if a file is large, in such a way that the minimap slider lines up with the scrollbar slider
* the minimap ignores view zones, in such cases its slider "shrinks" to reflect the visible lines in the viewport
* the minimap correctly updates when doing edits (removing multiple lines, changing a single line, adding multiple lines, etc.)
* you can click on the minimap (not on the slider at this point) and the viewport will change to reveal the clicked line in the center.


Please simply try it out, any feedback is appreiciated.

[Known issues](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3Aeditor-minimap)

data.title: Intellisense replaces correct path when manually typed
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-08T23:31:51.320Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0 (OSX El Capitan 10.11.6)
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.5|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.8|
|tslint|eg2|0.8.1|
|docthis|joelday|0.3.11|


Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a project with two files: `ThisProject/src/app/actions/comment.ts` and `ThisProject/src/app/components/CommentsPage.tsx`
2. Add a `tsconfig.json` that sets `"paths": { "app": ["./src/app"], "app/*": ["./src/app/*"] }`
1. Edit `CommentsPage.tsx`
1. Type in `import * as commentActions from 'app/actions/comment';`

Expected: Intellisense does nothing
Actual: When I type the last `'`, Intellisense replaces `'app/actions/comment'` with `'app/*'`

http://imgur.com/a/Chw0J

data.title: Test: Terminal Links
data.body:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/7321

- [x] Linux @joaomoreno 
- [x] macOS @kieferrm 
- [x] Windows @alexandrudima 

Complexity: 3

Terminals now add links for URLs and text that looks like a local path. Clicking URLs will open the default browser, clicking files will open the file in an editor. Note that folders will also be links but they will just not do anything, this behavior is expected.

Here are the specific text forms that will be "linkified":

- URLs qualified with `http://` or `https://`
- On Linux/macOS paths in the forms: `./x`, `../x`, `~/x`, `/x`
- On Windows paths in the forms: `.\x`, `..\x`, `~\x` (`~` points at `%HOMEDRIVE%\%HOMEPATH%`), `y:\x`. Windows links also allow mixed slashes, so `.\x\y`, `./x\y`, `./x/y` are all valid

data.title: [Suggestion] minimap: ability to drag and drop the "window"
data.body:
It would be great if:

 - it was possible to click and drag the "selection window" to move onto the minimap: releasing the mouse would show the text at current position
 - the minimap didn't scroll and was showing the whole document: right now, depending on the document size, you first have to scroll a little to view the part where you want to navigate to, and then only you make click on the position you want to move the view

What I call "window" is the highlighed square that indicates what part of the document is currently visible:

![window](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199648/23186680/35443100-f888-11e6-8cf4-c345b276e242.png)

data.title: [extensions] Add support for a RelatedFilesProvider

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: `1.10.0-insider` 25c55638340197fc9c8767aba9d32a0c29ccf68a
- OS Version: macOS Sierra `10.12.3 (16D32)`

I just put out a preview of a new extension [Find Related](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=eamodio.find-related) to be able to quickly jump to files related to the current file. It currently has a tiny set of rules (hopefully will be quickly expanded), but it got me thinking that it could be nice if this was something that was baked into vscode.

So just like the other `*Provider` types an extension could register a new `RelatedFilesProvider` (or something similar) that would allow vscode to show a quick pick of the results (and other extensions could use for other reasons/UI)

Hopefully this make sense.

data.title: Inconsistent wrapping behaviour
data.body:
I'm getting some odd behaviour with wrapping. I'm not using a workspace settings file, but I have a global setting of `"editor.wrappingColumn": 75` 

Yet, I have two markdown files which display differently (this with `--extensions-disabled`). Please note, 

I'm running this on Arch (Antergos), but my Mac seems to behave the same way. 

Version 1.9.1
Commit f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519
Date 2017-02-08T23:44:55.542Z
Shell 1.4.6
Renderer 53.0.2785.143
Node 6.5.0

relevant settings:

    }
        "editor.wordWrap": true, // toggling `false` makes no difference
        "editor.wrappingColumn": 75
    }

![unwrapped](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1544859/23178893/acf34990-f831-11e6-9e6d-bddd13742dd8.png)
![wrapped](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1544859/23178897/b092c684-f831-11e6-9864-a54d2e61ae4b.png)


I don't think I'm misunderstanding the way these settings work. And, either way, with identical settings, shouldn't they at least render the same way?

data.title: Co-maintainer with push access to extension marketplace gone. Is it possible for me to get push access?
data.body:
[Posted this question in stack overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/42376918/primary-maintainer-gone-i-was-added-to-help-maintain-but-have-no-push-access-t), but was quickly told that it wasn't the place for it. So now I'm not sure where to ask. Sorry in advance.

Here's the question again:

I was recently added to a syntax theme repo to help maintain after the original maintainer has gone rogue.

The issue I'm having is that I'm unable to push to the extension marketplace. How would I go about getting access if I have no contact with the original maintainer?

Allow me to quickly answer what I'm sure will be the first question asked:

> "How were you added as a maintainer without contact to the original maintainer?"

The theme is a repository within a github organization containing repos across many different editors. The organization owner granted me contributor access, however he does not have push access to the vscode marketplace either.

Repo: https://github.com/dracula/visual-studio-code

data.title: Test: Copy with syntax highlight
data.body:
- [x] win @bpasero 
- [x] os x @mjbvz 
- [x] linux @jrieken 

Complexity: 3
Refs: #3518 

We now support copy text with syntax highlighting. Please test against different themes and paste them into applications that support formatted text pasting, eg, MS product, Evernote.

data.title: Test: Drag and drop
data.body:
- [x] anyos @weinand (macOS)
- [x] anyos @aeschli  (linux)

Complexity: 2
Refs: #1046 

We now support drag and drop selected range inside an editor. We try to mimic the behavior of browser but it cannot be totally the same. Please see if the behavior looks reasonable to you, especially following edge cases

Enable drag and drop by setting:
```json
"editor.enableDragAndDrop": true
```


* drag to beginning/end of file
* drop at start/end of selected text
* drag off the editor window

Please note that below features are not supported yet

* drag to top/bottom of editor window to cause scrolling
* drag to edge of window on long line to drop at the end of line
* copy instead of move if Ctrl is held

data.title: File opens two tabs with inconsistent edits in each?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Duplicate file tab opens on its own, with incorrect file-name capitalization, and showing corrupted/inconsistent/incomplete edits that were being performed in the originally opened tab.

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  create ts file 'Container.js'
2.  add code and save
3.  rename the file using the vscode file explorer, to  ... 'container.ts' (changed cap C to lowercase c)
4.  open file in tab to make edits ... while editing code ...
5.  a new tab opens as 'Container.ts' with same content. ... two tabs (container.ts, Container.ts)
6.  while editing, each tab shows incomplete and inconsistent edits.
7.  often, closing the Container.ts file, then saving the container.ts file creates an error ...
     'File on disk is newer than file being saved.'
8.  Note: only one file exists in the file explorer window ... (container.ts)  
9.  renamed file 'container.ts' to 'newContainer.ts' and problem no longer exists

data.title: Escape paths in npm.sh to fix #20907
data.body:
I had cloned vscode into a folder within iCloud Drive `~/Library/Mobile Documents/com~apple~CloudDocs/vscode` and on `./scripts/npm.sh i` I was getting:

```
usage: dirname path
usage: dirname path
cat: /package.json: No such file or directory
```

This pull request adds escaping (not tested on Linux). Closes #20907.
